{"step_by_step_thinking": "The target sign is a radiological finding seen on imaging studies, particularly on CT scans. It refers to a concentric ring-like appearance with a central hypodense area surrounded by a hyperdense rim. This finding is typically seen in cases of spontaneous CSF rhinorrhea, which is the leakage of cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) through the nose without any history of trauma. Traumatic CSF rhinorrhea, on the other hand, is caused by a fracture or injury to the skull base. Therefore, the correct answer is A. Spontaneous CSF Rhinorrhea.", "answer_choice": "A"}
